importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The year when the LEAP trial results were published and initial public health guidelines for early peanut introduction in infants were issued, marking a turning point in allergy prevention practices.
The year when expanded guidelines for early allergen introduction were issued, leading to a more widespread adoption and greater impact on peanut allergy rates among children.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The decade-long period during which the implementation of early peanut exposure guidelines has led to measurable declines in peanut allergy incidence, demonstrating long-term public health impact.

keyTakeAways: The rate of peanut allergies in children aged 0 to 3 declined by more than 27% after 2015 and by over 40% after 2017 due to early introduction of peanuts in infancy.
About 40,000 children have avoided peanut allergies since 2015, according to the study.

Early introduction of peanut products—such as peanut butter, milk-based yogurt, soy-based yogurt, and tree nut butters—is recommended between 4 and 6 months of age, without prior screening or testing.

The LEAP (Learning Early About Peanut Allergy) trial, led by Gideon Lack at King’s College London, showed that early exposure reduces future food allergy risk by over 80%, with protection persisting in about 70% of children into adolescence.

Despite strong scientific evidence, adoption of early allergen introduction practices has been slow, with only about 29% of pediatricians and 65% of allergists reporting adherence to updated guidelines.
Advocacy groups like Food Allergy Research & Education (FARE) support the shift, emphasizing that early exposure is a proven and safe way to reduce the prevalence of food allergies nationwide.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A decade after the LEAP trial demonstrated that introducing peanuts to infants as early as four months reduces the risk of developing peanut allergies by over 80%, new research shows a significant decline in peanut allergy rates in the U.S. — with a 27% drop after 2015 and over 40% after 2017 — resulting in approximately 40,000 children avoiding peanut allergies. This shift is attributed to updated medical guidelines, which now recommend introducing allergenic foods like peanut butter, milk-based yogurt, and soy-based products between 4 and 6 months of age without prior screening. Despite initial slow adoption due to confusion among healthcare providers, real-world data from pediatric practices now show that early allergen exposure is being adopted and has made a measurable public health impact. Experts, advocacy groups, and clinicians agree that this evidence-based approach represents a meaningful opportunity to reduce the prevalence of food allergies nationwide.
title: Early Peanut Introduction in Infants Reduces Allergy Rates: New Research Confirms Public Health Impact
